text:
‘Yeah, I totally get you. But let me explain…’ Raskolnikov chimed in, trying to get through to Nikodim Fomitch while also catching Ilya Petrovitch’s attention. But Ilya was too busy digging through his papers, acting like Raskolnikov didn’t even exist. ‘I’ve been living with her for almost three years, and at first… well, I promised to marry her daughter. It was just a verbal promise, nothing serious… I liked her, but I wasn’t in love. Just a young fling, you know? My landlady was cool about giving me credit back then, and I was pretty careless…’

‘No one cares about your life story, sir. We don’t have time for this,’ Ilya Petrovitch cut in, sounding pretty pleased with himself. But Raskolnikov wasn’t having it; he shot back, struggling to find his words. 

‘But wait, wait. I need to explain how it all went down… I know it seems unnecessary, but a year ago, the girl died from typhus. I kept living there, and when my landlady moved to her new place, she told me, in a friendly way, that she trusted me completely. But she wanted me to write her an I O U for one hundred and fifteen roubles, which was the total debt I owed her. She said if I did that, she would trust me again and wouldn’t use the I O U until I could pay her back. And now, with no lessons and nothing to eat, she’s…’

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Raskolnikov explains his complicated relationship with his landlady and the circumstances leading to his current financial troubles.
